<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 276, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9702/53  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 411, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 5 Planning, Analysis and Evaluation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 300, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2022

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 558]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 602]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 30.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Two parallel metal plates, each of area \(A\), are separated by a small distance \(d\), as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[292, 117, 725, 255]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 272, 591, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 303, 561, 322]]<|/det|>
The plates are initially charged using a power supply.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 335, 920, 368]]<|/det|>
The plates are then connected to an uncharged capacitor. The potential difference \(V\) across the capacitor is measured.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 381, 567, 399]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(V\) is related to \(d\) by the relationship

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 403, 552, 435]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{W}{V} = 1 + \frac{Cd}{KA}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 443, 712, 462]]<|/det|>
where C is the capacitance of the capacitor, and \(K\) and \(W\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 475, 693, 492]]<|/det|>
Plan a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between \(V\) and \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 505, 625, 523]]<|/det|>
Draw a diagram showing the arrangement of your equipment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 536, 707, 554]]<|/det|>
Explain how the results could be used to determine values for \(K\) and \(W\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 567, 383, 585]]<|/det|>
In your plan you should include:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 599, 393, 616]]<|/det|>
● the procedure to be followed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 628, 410, 644]]<|/det|>
● the measurements to be taken

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 658, 346, 674]]<|/det|>
● the control of variables

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 688, 351, 704]]<|/det|>
● the analysis of the data

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 717, 447, 733]]<|/det|>
● any safety precautions to be taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the relationship between the luminosity \(L\) of a star and its mass \(M\) for a set of stars known as main-sequence stars.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 576, 137]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(L\) and \(M\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 149, 541, 168]]<|/det|>
\[L = SZM^n\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 180, 646, 199]]<|/det|>
where \(S\) is the luminosity of the Sun, and \(Z\) and \(n\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 211, 144, 230]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 211, 688, 230]]<|/det|>
A graph is plotted of \(\lg L\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(\lg M\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 241, 611, 260]]<|/det|>
Determine expressions for the gradient and \(y\)-intercept.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[497, 443, 917, 461]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 473, 920, 492]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 490, 920, 508]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 494, 89]]<|/det|> Values of \(M\) and \(L\) are given in Table 2.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 102, 539, 120]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 133, 878, 420]]<|/det|>
\(M/10^{30}kg\)\(L/10^{28}W\)\(\lg \left(M/10^{30}\mathrm {kg}\right)\)\(\lg \left(L/10^{28}\mathrm {W}\right)\)
4.8 ± 0.41.4
6.4 ± 0.43.1
12 ± 232
23 ± 2350
43 ± 43600
91 ± 466000
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 432, 784, 451]]<|/det|> Calculate and record values of \(\lg \left(M/10^{30}\mathrm {kg}\right)\) and \(\lg \left(L/10^{28}\mathrm {W}\right)\) in Table 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 446, 581, 465]]<|/det|> Include the absolute uncertainties in \(\lg \left(M/10^{30}\mathrm {kg}\right)\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 448, 920, 466]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 478, 144, 497]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 478, 180, 497]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 477, 621, 497]]<|/det|> Plot a graph of \(\lg \left(L/10^{28}\mathrm {W}\right)\) against \(\lg \left(M/10^{30}\mathrm {kg}\right)\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 492, 495, 512]]<|/det|> Include error bars for \(\lg \left(M/10^{30}\mathrm {kg}\right)\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 494, 920, 512]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 524, 180, 544]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 524, 920, 559]]<|/det|> Draw the straight line of best fit and a worst acceptable straight line on your graph. Label both lines. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 541, 920, 560]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 572, 180, 590]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 571, 920, 604]]<|/det|> Determine the gradient of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[497, 790, 920, 809]]<|/det|>
gradient = ............................................................ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 181, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Determine the \(y\)-intercept of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 256, 920, 275]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 288, 148, 306]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 287, 920, 320]]<|/det|>
Using your answers to (a), (c)(iii) and (c)(iv), determine the values of \(n\) and \(Z\). Include the absolute uncertainties in your values. You need not be concerned with units.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 333, 369, 351]]<|/det|>
Data: \(S = 3.85 \times 10^{26} \text{W}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 551, 917, 570]]<|/det|>
<form>n = ................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 581, 917, 600]]<|/det|>
<form>Z = ................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 598, 920, 616]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 630, 144, 648]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 628, 628, 647]]<|/det|>
Another main-sequence star has a mass of \(3.0 \times 10^{30} \text{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 660, 473, 677]]<|/det|>
Determine the luminosity \(L\) of this star.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 819, 920, 838]]<|/det|>
<form>L = .................................................... W [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 851, 920, 868]]<|/det|>
